comments: participants are divided into groups of 4 persons (teams); and then they aggregate the individuals' scores on the Big-5 into a team score for extraversion etc. Then; they correlated these team-big 5 scores with one another (e.g.; extraversion and neuroticism) and check whether there are significant correlations between these scores. The groups are not statistically compared; only the scores on the big-5. So I would say no group comparison is made.

author: moreira
name_scale: Battery of cognitive test (MMSE (cognition) + SRT (only certain domains; measures memory))
comments: Width scale: combination of different type of scales. These two scales are combined in one measurement model over time (so 2 * 2 factors). "By means of a confirmatory factor analysis approach; we tested whether a two-factor solution [corresponding to measures of memory performance (MEM) and executive functioning (EXEC)] was reliable over time. Nested models of longitudinal invariance demonstrated the existence of partial strong invariance over time. In other words; this indicates that there is an equivalence of the factorial structure and factor loadings for all items; this was also observed for the item intercepts for all the items; except for one of the items from the EXEC dimension."

The same goes for ISSU radio message (5 items); General TV (2 items); ISSU TV message (7 items); and ISSU community activities (4 items). I think the results of these items are combined together and then regressed. We coded as non-reflective scale; because no psychometric properties; internal consistency; references etc.

author: theunissen
power: "If the true difference between mean SFQ scores assessed one week before surgery and assessed on the morning on the day of surgery is five; we would need to study 93 subjects in order to be able to reject the null hypothesis that this response difference is zero with a power set at 0.8. Based on prior data [11;15] we assumed a standard deviation of 17 for the difference between SFQ scores. The Type I error probability associated with this test of this null hypothesis was 0.05. With an additional nine patients for correction of drop-out; 102 patients would need to be included."
comments: Comparisons are conducted for the two dimensions so they are reported for each dimension

author: lemaignan
comments: No statistical group comparisons. They refer to a construct: SCCS (social attitude): "The SCCS consists in 6 mutually exclusive constructs characterising social communication (hostile; pro-social; assertive; passive; adult seeking; irrelevant) and were specifically created to characterise children’s communication in a classroom setting. We transposed these constructs from the communication domain to the general behavioural domain; keeping the pro-social; hostile (whose scope we broadened in adversarial); assertive (i.e. dominant); and passive constructs. In our scheme; the adult seeking and irrelevant constructs belong to Task Engagement axis." However; these are constructs that can be ascribed to children's behavior by the annotaters; and is not quantitavely coded.

author: singh
name_group: lower L2 proficiency group and higher L2 proficiency group
comments: language background questionnaire is adapted. They seem to analyze this scale separately per item in the table; but the text says: "We found a significant difference between the two groups; t (61) = -5.21; p = .001; which suggests that the difference in self-rated proficiency in L1 and L2 was significantly lower for high-proficiency bilinguals (0.32) compared to low proficient bilinguals (2.12).". It seems like they combined the scale.

author: singh
name_group: lower L2 proficiency group and higher L2 proficiency group
comments: the authors split up the group based on the scores on the LexTale test and picture description task and then do main analyses. The main analysis is on reaction time (not a scale); but the way the groups are selected is based on scales. There is also a no go/go group; but they don't get compared for scales.

author: Kim
comments: DVs is one item: perceiving tnese form differently; checked with time window analysis. Multiple trials are measured.

author: Kim
comments: DVs are proportion of clicks; proportion of fixation etc. All separate items.

comments: application of user-based algorithms (no subjects)

author: parra-fernandez
comments: Validation study on one group in which they use PCA. They do state this; but not any group comparisons are made beyond this: "Finally; the main investigator of the present study administered the questionnaire to a small group of Spanish students (n = 20) to check the readability and understandability of items and the cognitive equivalence of the translation."

author: schiavon
comments: animal study

comments: multiple trials measured; mean of all taken for DVs. DVs are movement data

comments: multiple trials measured; mean of all taken for DVs. DVs are movement data

comments: multiple trials measured; mean of all taken for DVs. DVs are movement data

author: Birmingham
comments: DVs are accuracy; response time; percentage of exploration time; last ROI explored; and correlations between two variables. None of these are scales or combined to form a scale; but the mean is taken over multiple trials.

author: Shafiei
comments: sample is 27 medical students who record EEG data. Study investigtes whether robot-human interaction (RAS skill acquisition) results in reconfiguration of brain functional states. These brain functional states are then the DVs; and they are investigated as separate items (see table 3). No group comparison is made.

author: Wang
comments: subjects are maize plants; intelligent weed control methods are tested

author: schoenaker
comments: three scales: smoking behavior; SES; and anti-smoking social norms. Anti-smoking norms items are analyzed separtely; SES are combined but this is not a reflective scale (no reference; no psychometric analysis; no internal consistency); and smoking behavior the same (unsure if these items are combined).

author: jiang
comments: Childhood Trauma Questionnaire (CTQ-SF) validation study for schizophrenia patients. No group comparisons are made.

author: peng
comments: weather and traffic (probably included in the data because of the subject term 'intelligence')

comments: MRI measurements

author: monroy
milevel_rep: DVs are "the length of time to habituate to a visual stimulus; and look-away rate during habituation". These scores are combined as a scale and compared between hearing and deaf infants; so I would say not reflective.

author: jewkes
name_group: boys: control and schools and families and schools
name_scale: Learner measure: Incidence of non-partner rape
power: They state their study is very underpowered. The statement about power is: "We anticipated 250 students per grade enrolling in the study and that allowed for about 20% loss to follow up; or fewer initially recruited. The sample size calculation required an estimate of k; the between cluster coefficient of variation of the outcome measure; we used k = 0.20. A sample size of 8 clusters per trial arm would then give more than 80% power to detect as statistically significant at the 5% level a 50% reduction in IPV incidence."
comments: Sample sizes from table 3. Almost all scales are either adapted or developed for the study: "Where we developed our own measures; we first reviewed other measures/scales on related topics; then as a study team went through and adapted where we thought necessary based on our previous experience doing research with similar populations in South Africa; then we piloted the questionnaire with a few pupils to ensure that items were understood."

power: They state their study is very underpowered. The statement about power is: "We anticipated 250 students per grade enrolling in the study and that allowed for about 20% loss to follow up; or fewer initially recruited. The sample size calculation required an estimate of k; the between cluster coefficient of variation of the outcome measure; we used k = 0.20. A sample size of 8 clusters per trial arm would then give more than 80% power to detect as statistically significant at the 5% level a 50% reduction in IPV incidence."
comments: This scale has a reference to another article without "adapted from".

author: llewellyn
name_group: control group (routine care) and intervention group
power: "Ethical amendment was approved to alter the original analysis plan from mixed affects ANCOVAs to mixed effects negative binomial models and linear models to better take into account missing data and the original power calculation relates to the original protocol [23] S1 and S2 Files. We have not retrospectively applied a power calculation to the data [24]."
comments: I am unsure whether the comparison between control and intervention is based on baseline; 4 months; 8 months; or 12 months. The N is the reported N from a table; but the N differs between scales; but I don't know if I should report baseline or any of the other time samples. The scale was adapted from a validated scale.

author: abdin
name_group: ages (young: 20 to 39 years; middle: 40 to 59 years; older: 60 years and above)
name_scale: CBI (burnout) and PHQ-2 (depression and anhedonia); Factor Job Demand
comments: the authors use two scales (CBI and PHQ) and extract five factors from these two scales. These five factors are then compared for all groups. Therefore I split the scales into 5 (with 6 groups makes 30 rows) and coded name_scale with both scales combined. The CBI and PHQ are not investigated separately. Not sure which kind of DIF is found.  The MIMIC was used (and applied to the whole scale) but since the analysis was performed item by item I indicated that an IRT approach was used.

author: meerza
comments: The DV is willingness to pay (WTP): "We used the demand-revealing Becker-DeGroot-Marschak (BDM) mechanism [14] to elicit consumers’ valuation of Italian EVOO. In the BDM mechanism; subjects submit a bid; representing their maximum WTP; for a good that is presented to them by the experimenter. After the subject has submitted their bid; an “experiment” price is randomly drawn from a distribution of prices. If the bid is higher than the randomly drawn experiment price; the participant purchases the good but pays only the experiment price. If the bid is lower than the experiment price; the participant does not purchase the good. "

author: yue
comments: They compare two scales (Bayley-3 and ASQ-3 across one group of children); so there is no comparison between groups. However; Table 5 depicts subgroup analysis of the subscales in different age groups. However; they still only compare correlations of items within each group; and do not make a group comparison ACROSS groups. As such; coded it as no groups compared.

author: liu
comments: "The difference between the two groups at each time point from 0–3 months up until 22–24 months were statistically significant with at the 5% level (p-value < 0.01)."; so they compared each group (non-bereaved and bereaved) at each time point for each level of well-being-- The satisfaction items are single items; no scale. Low social activity also measured by only one item? -- They don't give a reference for the SF-36 well-being scale.

author: liu
comments: "The difference between the two groups at each time point from 0–3 months up until 22–24 months were statistically significant with at the 5% level (p-value < 0.01)."; so they compared each group (non-bereaved and bereaved) at each time point for each level of well-being; I think. So technically these 5 rows need to be extended times 7 timepoints? -- The satisfaction items are single items; no scale. Low social activity also measured by only one item? -- They don't give a reference for the SF-36 well-being scale.

author: Orozco-Olvera
comments: meta-analysis

author: cavenagh
name_group: female carrier group and normative sample
comments: power estimate based on n = 85; but in reality they have more. the authors do compare groups on scales; but the group the female carries are compared to are not participants the authors sampled themselves; but reported mean scores from these groups in other articles. As such; the authors should have checked for measurement invariance; but since they probably didn't have the data from the other group; they could not do so. We also could not do so. I did code this as a group comparison because they *should* have done so before writing this article.

"Each condition consisted of 72 trials that also had 2 patterns; namely; combinations of the following stimuli: left-to-right-walking Go (Go-left stimulus) and Stop (Stop stimulus); and right-to-left-walking Go (Go-right stimulus) and Stop. In each pattern; Go (Go-left or Go-right) and Stop stimuli appeared 18 times in random order. During the experiments; the reaction times were always recorded".

author: bourdel
comments: systematic review on scales

author: klaus
comments: mathematical model

author: Steyaert
comments: systematic review on scale

author: Noorai
comments: animal study

author: verigen
name_group: poor liars and neutral liars and good liars
comments: Open and closed questions are provided to participants. The open questions are then coded via qualitative analysis; and the closed questions are single items which are not combined in a scale: "Participants provided an open-ended response to explain “In general; what strategy or strategies do you use when telling lies?” They were then asked to rate on a 10-point Likert scale (1 –not important to 10 –very important) how important they consider verbal strategies of deception and nonverbal strategies of deception to be for getting away with lies (for the definitions provided to participants; see the Supporting Information). Finally; participants indicated which verbal strategies they use when telling lies in general from a pre-determined set (options: reporting from previous experience; providing details the person cannot check [i.e.; unverifiable details]; telling a plausible story; etcetera). "

author: dos Santos
comments: the authors tally frequencies of certain actions (items) that are performed by the school; across four dimensions: "The most common items associated with that dimension involved the relationship between preceptors and students (13 schools; 26.5%; 95%CI: 16.2–40.3%); preceptors and patients/families (7 schools; 14.3%; 95%CI: 7.1%-26.7%); preceptors and the multidisciplinary healthcare team (3 schools). The instruments of only 2 (4.1%; 95%CI: 1.1–13.7%) schools included 1 question regarding specifically the experience of negative ethical events during a rotation and just 1 (2.0%; 95%CI: 0.4–10.7%) school asked for positive ethical experiences."

author: Martin
comments: animal data; so coded as non-empirical

author: ngo
comments: Memory Task is measured by accuracy of 144 trials. There are no references; psychometric properties or internal consistency. Verbal intelligence is also a scale; but only used as a control variable within each age group. Retrieval dependency is measured by "the proportion of events in which both associations were either correctly or incorrectly retrieved".

author: jee
power: "this sample size provided power of greater than .90 to detect a medium to large effect (Cohen’s ƒ2≥ .25) for our planned analysis"
comments: Other scales that are measured but either used to divide subjects into groups; or not statistically tested in the main manuscript but in the supplemental materials: Peabody Picture Vocabulary Test; Spatial Relations subtest of the Primary Mental Abilities test. See also: "We also analyzed participants’ spatial-test perfor-mance before and after instruction for both Experiments 1 and 2. The details are provided in the Supplemental Material. In short; we found no change in mental-rotation performance in either experiment. Perspective-taking scores increased significantly in both experiments; however; the control and instructional conditions showed about the same level of improvement.". Since we don't know between which groups are compared on the spatial test and the mental rotation performance; I did not include these scales here.

author: Kievit
power: "With our current model specification and sample size; we had 73% power to detect a small coupling effect (r = .1; as defined by Gignac & Szodorai; 2016) but effectively 100% power to detect intermediate (r = .2) and large (r = .3) effects."
comments: Only measurement invariance is mentioned but nothing else. "As before; a multigroup model with gender as the grouping factor provided no evidence for differences". They also have multiple waves; but as far as I can see they only compare the model fit across the three waves; without testing for actual differences in vocabulary or matrix reasoning between these waves. MI-test:  "As before; we imposed measurement invariance for the g-factor model across occasions." The authors also state in their limitations/future research that fitting a MI model over time would be better.

comments: The authors use scales (e.g. psychological well-being; depression; anxiety; denial) but there do not appear to be group comparisons.

author: Persson
name_group: Cyberball inclusion vs Cyberball exclusion task
comments: Authors compared social distress in the cyberball tas based on genetic differences. No reliability reported. self-reported social distres was measured around four dimensions which each 5 items but it appears only the total scale is analyzed. The actual DV is the difference between the mean stress level after the first cyberball task and the mean stress level after the second cyberball task. Other DVs that are being measured are: "the difference in dictator giving between the two dictator games; proposals in the ultimatum game; social distress and anger for unfair proposals in the ultimatum game; amount sent to the trustee in the trust game; and finally; social distress and anger for betrayal in the trust game. ". These seem to be all separate items; and they do not refer to psychometric properties or references or internal consistency.

". These seem to be all separate items; and they do not refer to psychometric properties or references or internal consistency.

author: vuletich
comments: the authors do a re-analysis of 2014 data; for which it is unclear whether they have total IAT scores (no MI possible) or individual item scores for IAT (MI possible). It appears to be a total score; so I didn’t code it as a scale. The authors also make a composite index of structural inequalities; for which they have a cronbach's alpha estimate; but they do not compare this index between groups; just with IAT scores.

author: hotaling
comments: The authors do 5 experiments but combine all data and analyze is together. As such; I combined comparisons across all these studies as well. Multiple trials of sampling from a box with balls is carried out; and I assume that each choice is then combined across trials for each participant in a mean: "To better understand the task; consider an example trial involving a riskier option on the left; offering a 10% chance of winning $16; and a safer option on the right; offering an 80% chance of winning $2. When sampling from the riskier box; participants would observe one blue ball and nine red balls; from the safer box; they would sample eight blue balls and two red balls." "The values of boxes (monetary gambles) were determined as follows. Each choice alternative was defined by a reward value; ν (range = $1–$21); and a probability of reward; π (range = .083–1)".

author: hotaling

When sampling from the riskier box; participants would observe one blue ball and nine red balls; from the safer box; they would sample eight blue balls and two red balls." Another DV is Scale for Intrasexual Competition but this scale is only used to divide subjects; it is not compared between groups.

author: dorfman
comments: DV is learning rate of hidden-agent interventions across trials: "After choosing an action and observing reward rt on trial t; participants updated their estimates of the action’s intrinsic reward probability θt according to a reinforcement-learning equation that depends on inferences about latent uses: θt + 1 = θt + αt (rt – θt); where αt is a learn-ing rate. The learning rate changed across trials depend-ing on the posterior probability of the hidden-agent intervention; as computed by Bayes’s rule."

The learning rate changed across trials depend-ing on the posterior probability of the hidden-agent intervention; as computed by Bayes’s rule."

author: Hakim
comments: "We aggregated data across Experiments 1 and 2". They measure two tasks; working memory and attention; but they don't compare groups on these tasks. Rather; WM and Attention are two different groups that are compared. All outcomes are EEG; eye movement; blinks; drift; pupil dilation; horizontal gaze. 80 trials in total. I did not code this as non-empirical because there is human behavioral data in the WM and attention tasks.

I did not code this as non-empirical because there is human behavioral data in the WM and attention tasks.

author: madan
comments: The DV is participants support for resettling refugees. Participants’ mind-sets about the kind of person someone is; mindset about intelligence and political orientation are also used and are latent variables; but these variables are used as IVs (no groups). Additionally; the article states "respond to the resettling refugees measure first vs. complete the mindsets measures first" is a group; but this comparison is not made in the article. As such; I cannot find a group comparison in study 1.

author: madan
name_group: fixed-mind-set condition or the growth-mind-set condition
power: "To conduct the power analysis; we used the effect size from Study 5 by Chiu et al. (1997); as the current study used the same experimental manipula-tion. Using G*Power software (Faul et al.; 2007); we com-puted a power analysis for a t test comparing two independent means; Cohen’s d= 0.61; α= .05 (two-tailed); power = 80%; allocation ratio across conditions =1; which indicated that we would need to recruit a mini-mum of 88 participants. However; to ensure that the study was highly powered; we decided to recruit 400 participants"
comments: scale was adapted from other study

author: Smith
comments: This study uses 6 eye tracking datasets; but interpret all results together so I coded only one line. They do compare different model fits; but there are no comparisons made between groups. The only comparison I can find is between high and low values for each dataset: "We observed a positive difference between high and low values in five out of six data sets (see Fig. 4c). Results of one-tailed paired-samples t tests on each individual data set were mostly marginal or nonsignificant— Data Set 1: t(37) = 1.99; p = .027; Data Set 2: t(43) = 1.20; p = .119; Data Set 3: t(43) = 0.74; p = .233; Data Set 4: t(32) = −0.57; p = .713; Data Set 5: t(19) = 1.00; p = .166; Data Set 6: t(42) = 1.44; p = .079. " The outcome variable seems to be a beta coefficient for individual subjects; so I did not code this as a scale.

author: Kim
comments: meta-analysis

author: denissen
comments: The Big 5 is measured but then split up into 5 dimensions; and within these dimensions comparisons are made between job personality demands (X; other-report) and income (Y); both not dummies

author: heyman
comments: No group comparisons made; only one sample t-tests. This is the procedure: ""The main experiment comprised 160 trials; split up in four blocks of 40 trials each. Between blocks; participants could take a self-paced break." "After securing 90 participants who met the inclusion criteria and after completing the data-cleaning procedure; we calculated the average suppression time for each Condition × Participant combination. Subsequently; a difference score was obtained for each participant by subtracting the average suppression time in the congruent condition from the average suppression time in the incongruent condition. "

author: perkovic
comments: DV is one item; other-rating of how healthful certain food is: "Next; we compared the estimated healthfulness of conventional and organic foods. We found that organic foods (M = 4.47; SD = 1.48) were; on average; 30% more healthful than conventional foods (M = 3.44; SD = 1.59); d = 0.65."

author: perkovic
comments: In the result section of study 2 they compare the results of study 2 with study 1 through correlates (no comparisons made). However; in text they interpret that the procedure in study 2 was almost the same in study 1; meaning that there probably was a group comparison in ratings of healthfulness between organic and conventional foods. Because there are no group comparisons reported; I did not code it as such.

author: perkovic
comments: DV is eye tracking data; and participants appear to only view one set of foods; for which the data is extracted. "The analysis revealed no significant main effect of condition; χ2(2; N = 71) = 0.63; p = .73; a significant main effect of label type"

author: gottlieb
name_group: Rating dimension (between-subjects factor): introspection-phenomenology; human uniqueness; abnormal functioning; conscious will; importance for identity; complexity
comments: DVs are scientific possibility and scientific comfort; which are combined and analyzed separately. "Participants rated 46 mental traits; abilities; or phenomena (presented in a random order) on two measures of scientific explanation: “Science could one day fully explain ___” (scientific possibility) and “I am uncomfortable with the idea that science could one day fully explain ___”." Participants were randomly assigned to rate the picture on either of 6 dimensions: introspection-phenomenology; human uniqueness; abnormal functioning; conscious will; importance for identity; complexity. "We first created means for each item’s scientific-possibility and scientific-comfort ratings using data from all participants. We then created means for each item corresponding to the six rated dimensions; in each case using data from the subset of participants who rated the corresponding dimension."

author: gottlieb
name_group: Rating dimension (privileged first-person access; introspection; subjective experience)
comments: DVs are the same in exp 1. "All participants again rated the 46 items for scientific possibility and scientific discomfort; and then each participant was assigned to rate each item on one of three additional dimensions that could have played a role in the introspection-phenomenology dimension identified in Study 1."

author: geary
comments: CPK was initially entered as a continuous variable; but later gets added as a categorical variable: "As we show in the Results section; the Bayes analyses identified time of achieving CPK status as an important predictor; and for the associated regression analyses; this was included as a five-level categorical variable." NSK is a composite of three tasks; factor analysis is done and one factor is extracted. As far as I can see; the only dummy variables (like parental education) are used as controls in a regression model. Other scales that are measured are used as predictors in regression models.

author: ackerman
power: "To determine sufficiently powered sample sizes in the following studies; we reviewed effect sizes of sev-eral previous tests of experimentally manipulated pathogen cues on responses to appearance-relevant stimuli (Ackerman et al.; 2009; Miller & Maner; 2012; White et al.; 2013). We observed an average d of 0.65. To compensate for potential effect-size inflation; we estimated a d of 0.45; which is closer to effect sizes obtained by field-wide meta-analyses (Richard; Bond; & Stokes-Zoota; 2003). This suggested that a sample size of 158 would be needed to detect an effect with 80% power."
comments: All info in supplemental materials

author: ackerman
power: "As part of our preregistration for this study (https://osf.io/zvhb8); we conducted a power analysis to determine appropriate sample size. Because this study was run in response to review feedback from an earlier submission; we were able to use the interaction effect size from the internal meta-analysis (r = .172) as an input to this power analysis. We converted this to an f2 value (0.03) and entered it into G*Power with the following assumptions: Multiple regression test (R2 deviation from zero); α err prob = .05; power = .95; number of predictors = 7 (two predictors; their interaction; and 4 outcome variables). This analysis suggested a total sample size of 735."
comments: All info in supplemental materials

author: ackerman
power: "As part of our preregistration for this study (https://osf.io/tsyrj/); we conducted a power analysis to determine appropriate sample size. First; we converted all R2 for the condition X PVDGA interactions in Studies 1-3 to rs and inputted these into the Comprehensive Meta-Analysis program (Studies 1-3 were used because Studies 5A & 5B were run chronologically before Study 4). This led to an estimated effect size of r = .253 for the interaction. This was converted back to an R2; which was then converted to an f2 value (0.0734). This was entered into G*Power with the following assumptions: Multiple regression test (R2 deviation from zero); α err prob = .05; power = .95; number of predictors = 5. This analysis suggested a total sample size of 276."
comments: All info in supplemental materials

author: ackerman
power: "As part of our preregistration for this study (https://osf.io/tsyrj/); we conducted a power analysis to determine appropriate sample size. author: Tong
comments: DV is Average Estimation Error: estimation of house price vs real house price in dollars; sum or average of 15 trials

author: Tong
name_group: subset of houses that were subsequently chosen and houses in general
comments: "The dependent variable was the subject’s estimate of a house’s price minus the actual sale price of that house: the error of the estimate. " "First; we computed each subject’s average estimation error for houses in general (18 estimations per subject)"

author: Tong
comments: DV is answer for one item; one question only: "They decided which hypothetical candidate to hire for an entry-level position".

author: Tong
comments: In one condition (choose) the subjects get 6 jars; then choose the jar they think have the most money; and the jar that thinks has the least amount of money. Then they estimate how much money is in both these jars. In the other condition (independent); the subject gets to see the 2 jars that the choose-subject chose (minimum and maximum) and is asked to estimate how much money is in both these jars. The DV is thus how much money is in both jars; which is a combination of two items. As such; I coded it as not a scale.

author: biderman
comments: 4 DVs: Subjective Visibility/Perceptual Awareness + Objective Congruency + Objective orientation/Visibiility posttest + Reaction Time: "Stimuli were 144 pairs of congruent and incongruent colored real-life scenes used in Mudrik and Koch (2013). " "First; they had to report target congruency as quickly and accurately as possible by pressing either the left arrow (“incongruent”) or the right arrow (“congruent”) on the keyboard." "After judging target congruency; subjects were asked to subjectively rate prime visibility using the 4-point Perceptual Awareness Scale (Ramsy & Overgaard; 2004); where 1 is “I didn’t see anything;” 2 signifies “I had a vague perception of something;” 3 represents “I saw a clear part of the image;” and 4 stands for “I saw the entire image clearly.”"

author: russell

author: kardas
comments: DV is participants own expectation of rating of their moonwalk; and their moonwalk rated by other people. The moonwalk rated by other people is an average across 100 judgments. "Then; raters watched and rated each of the 100 moonwalks; one at a time in randomized order; from 1 (pretty bad attempt) to 10 (pretty good attempt). Each rating screen was prefaced with the phrase “Compared to the original training video” and had a link to rewatch the training video if desired. Thus; each rater evaluated all 100 videos (i.e.; each moonwalk was evaluated by 100 different raters). As preregistered; we calculated the mean rating for each video and treated this mean as a single actual performance score for each performer; which could be directly compared with each performer’s predicted score."

author: kardas
power: "In this and all of our experiments; we predetermined sample sizes of at least 50 participants per cell (Simmons; Nelson; & Simonsohn; 2018); and we doubled this number or more for online experiments. This matches many cell sizes in past research using similar designs (e.g.; about 35 per cell in Carpenter; Wilford; Kornell; & Mullaney; 2013; about 30 per cell in Andrieux & Proteau; 2016; Baumeister; Alquist; & Vohs; 2015). In addition; we conducted power analyses using G*Power (Faul; Erdfelder; Lang; & Buchner; 2007). Cells of 50 provide 80% power to detect an effect size (d) of 0.57 (two-tailed; α = .05). The average size of the critical effect across experiments was 0.60 (N = 2;225); achieving 84% power. Our experiments appear to have been amply powered."

power: "Given our interest in achiev-ing a large sample size; we recruited participants from both an undergraduate subject pool at the University of California; Berkeley (n = 94); as well as Amazon’s Mechan-ical Turk (MTurk; n = 113) simultaneously. Because the study began late enough in the academic semester; it was clear that following Studies 1a and 1b’s sample size; determination guidelines would not be sufficient. The MTurk sample size was determined by taking the funding lab’s monthly MTurk budget and dividing it among stud-ies being run online that month. This split was not done evenly; but instead studies were weighted according to how many conditions they had and whether they were being run entirely online."

author: klein selle
comments: DVs: significance; arousal; and valence of the cards. These are the questions: "which card did you choose" (1 item) / "select correct card" (1 item) / "significance of 8 cards and 8 control cards" (so 16 items?) / "valence of 8 cards and 8 control cards" (so 16 items?) / "arousal of 8 cards and 8 control cards" (so 16 items?) / "motivation to conceal/reveal" (1 item) / "effort to conceal/reveal" (1 item) / "effort to inhibit arousal" (1 item) / "speed in selecting red or green circles" (1 item). This means that there are three scales I would say (significance; valence and arousal). The authors also state this; which I don't really understand; but it seems to mean they make mean scores for two variables for each participant: "Finally; for the decision-phase analyses; two dependent measures were created for each participant and each physiological measure (one for the conceal condition and one for the reveal condition) by averaging the raw scores across categories. In addition; for the CIT-phase analyses; two detection scores were created for each participant and each physiological measure (one for the conceal condition and one for the reveal condition) by averaging the respective z scores of the critical items. "

author: klein selle
comments: DVs: significance; arousal; and valence of the cards. These are the questions: "which card did you choose" (1 item) / "select correct card" (1 item) / "significance of 8 cards and 8 control cards" (so 16 items?) / "valence of 8 cards and 8 control cards" (so 16 items?) / "arousal of 8 cards and 8 control cards" (so 16 items?) / "motivation to conceal/reveal" (1 item) / "effort to conceal/reveal" (1 item) / "effort to inhibit arousal" (1 item) / "speed in selecting red or green circles" (1 item). This means that there are three scales I would say (significance; valence and arousal). The authors also state this; which I don't really understand; but it seems to mean they make mean scores for two variables for each participant: "Finally; for the decision-phase analyses; two dependent measures were created for each participant and each physiological measure (one for the conceal condition and one for the reveal condition) by averaging the raw scores across categories. In addition; for the CIT-phase analyses; two detection scores were created for each participant and each physiological measure (one for the conceal condition and one for the reveal condition) by averaging the respective z scores of the critical items. "

author: devitt
name_group: narrative version (going well vs going poorly)
comments: "For each simulated event; participants described aloud as much information as possible within 3 min; while being audio-recorded. At the end of the 3 min; a bell sounded to indicate that participants should stop talking; and they then rated the simulation on a 5-point scale for emotional valence (1 = strongly negative; 3 = neutral; 5 = strongly positive); vividness; personal significance; plausibility; and similarity to previous experiences (1 = low; 5 = high)". Other DVs are hits and false alarms; when participants performed a recognition test whether certain information was in the narrative or not.

author: guo
comments: DV: "We measured initiation time as the time elapsed from the onset of the go cue (first patch) to the onset of the movement and movement time as the time elapsed bet ween the beginning and end of the movement. Grasping-angle error was defined as the absolute angle difference between actual grasping angle and the orientation of the second Gabor patch." Over multiple trials: "after one practice block; participants performed 12 trial blocks; consisting of 6 blocks for each tilted-size condition (small or large). Each block consisted of 32 trials—8 trials for each grasping condition." they compare two conditions (small-size condition vs large-size condition) but the results are presented in the supplemental material; only one group presented in the manuscript.

author: jones
name_group: women using contraceptives and women not using contraceptives
comments:
DV is women’s masculinity preferences over multiple trials: "women were shown the 10 pairs of male faces; each pair consisting of a masculinized and feminized version of a given individual. Women were instructed to select the more attractive face in each pair and to indicate the strength of that preference by choosing from the options “slightly more attractive;” “somewhat more attractive;” “more attractive;” and “much more attractive." "Each woman’s average masculinity-preference score 
 was calculated separately for the short-term and long-term judgments for each test session. Higher scores indicate stronger masculinity preferences."

author: jones
name_group: women taking active pills versus when they were taking a scheduled break from active pills.
comments:
DV is women’s masculinity preferences over multiple trials: "women were shown the 10 pairs of male faces; each pair consisting of a masculinized and feminized version of a given individual. Women were instructed to select the more attractive face in each pair and to indicate the strength of that preference by choosing from the options “slightly more attractive;” “somewhat more attractive;” “more attractive;” and “much more attractive." "Each woman’s average masculinity-preference score 
 was calculated separately for the short-term and long-term judgments for each test session. Higher scores indicate stronger masculinity preferences."

author: Zhang
comments: DV is discount rate: "Discount rate was calculated as in the original study; using the hyper-bolic discounting formula k = (A/V – 1)/D; where Awas the indifference point; or the future amount that made participants indifferent between the present and future rewards; V was the present reward (i.e.; $120); and D was the delay (i.e.; 1 year)." The participants made 9 choices which were then put in this formula; so I didn't code it as a scale.

The participants made 9 choices which were then put in this formula; so I didn't code it as a scale.

author: lee
name_group: recall either an experiential or a material discretionary purchase
power: "The target sample size was determined at preregistration. A power analysis based on the average effect size from our meta-analysis (d = 0.34) indicated that a minimum of approximately 400 participants would be needed to obtain .80 power. Because the meta-analytic effect included within-participants and between-participants designs; an indirect measure of social class; and a relatively limited sample of participants (i.e.; col-lege students); we selected a target sample size of 500 to adequately power the key Purchase Type × Social Class interaction. "
comments: The MacArthur Scale of Subjective Social Status seems to be only one item. The authors do state that they investigated other indicators of social status in the supplemental materials; so these are not included in this codebook. As social status appears to be only one item; I did not include it here.

author: white
comments: "Dual-task deficits" and accuracy are the outcomes. DV is measured from multiple trials: " As a bias-free measure of accuracy; we computed the area under the receiver-operating-characteristic (ROC) curve; known as Green’s area or Ag (Pollack & Hsieh; 1969). Like proportion correct; Ag is a proportion that ranges from .5 (guessing) to 1.0 (perfect). ". The procedure: "The postcue remained visible until the participant pressed one of four keys with the hand on the same side as the postcue; reporting with a 1 to 4 rating the level of confidence that a target was present: “sure absent;” “guess absent;” “guess present;” or “sure present.” " There is another comparison made between left-hand and right-hand targets but the manuscript doesn't state which experiment this is; so I did not code it as a comparison here.

author: knapen
comments:
"The independent variables in the main model were participants’ own height in centimeters and their opponent’s height in centimeters. An additional model considered the participants’ relative height in centimeters (participant’s height – opponent’s height). The main dependent variables were the number of coins (out of 18) participants kept for themselves in a dictator game (M = 12.62; SD = 4.05) and the number of coins (also out of 18) participants kept for themselves in an ultimatum 
 game (M = 10.24; SD = 1.91). "

author: knapen
comments:
"participant height in centimeters and opponent height in centimeters were the main independent variables; and relative height was again an additional independent variable (participant height – opponent height). The main dependent vari-
 ables were the number of coins kept for self in the dictator game and (noninstrumental) direct aggression; as measured by the amount of hot sauce allocated to the opponent in a hot-sauce task (see Lieberman et al.; 1999)."

author: petrova
comments:
Since this is a commentary; it is unclearly reported what the conditions are that are compared. From table 2 I get that a t-test is done between two groups. The DV is a measure across multiple trials; combined into one estimate: "In each trial; a cue word 
 appeared at the center of the screen; and after a delay (stimulus onset asynchrony; SOA); the target appeared either above or below fixation until participants’ response. Participants were instructed to identify the subsequently presented target quickly and accurately by pressing the appropriate key.". The number of trials can be found in table 2 as well.

author: Kumar
comments:
DVs separate items: "Expressers first predicted how surprised the recipient would report feeling about receiving their letter on a scale ranging from 0 (not at all surprised) to 10 (extremely surprised)." / "They predicted how surprised the recipient would report feeling about the specific reasons for feeling grateful on a scale ranging from 0 (not at all surprised) to 10 (extremely surprised). Expressers then predicted how the letter would make the recipient feel on a scale ranging from −5 (much more negative than normal) to 5 (much more positive than normal); with the midpoint of 0 labeled no different than normal. Expressers also reported how writing the letter made them feel personally on the same scale. Finally; expressers predicted 
 how awkward the recipient “will report feeling after reading your letter” on a scale ranging from 0 (not at all awkward) to 10 (extremely awkward) and how awkward sending the letter made them feel on the same scale"

author: guassi moreira
name_group: relationship with parent and relationship with friend
power: Prior to data collection; we set each of the two sample sizes at 90 participants to be comparable with; or larger than; the sample sizes of other similar studies
comments: The main comparisons are made between condition (1 = parent gain/friend lose; 0 = friend gain/parent lose); but the scale that is used (relationship quality) is entered as a moderator here. Afterwards; paired-sampled t-tests are performed for relationship quality between parents and friends. The samples are combined here; as you can see from the dfs (total N = 174): "Although parent relationship quality and friend relationship quality were correlated (r = .229; p = .002); participants reported greater levels of relationship quality with their friend than with their parent (parent: M = 3.72; friend: M = 4.21); t(173) = −8.90; p < .001. Even though participants reported higher quality relationships with a close friend; they were still overall more likely to make choices that benefited a par-ent at the expense of their friend. These were preplanned exploratory analyses for our first sample and confirmatory analyses for the second sample.". The number of items differs per group: 25 for friend and 28 for parent. This means that there automatically is configural non-invariance.

author: block
power: We aimed to recruit at least 25 usable participants per age (in years) and gender (target n = 400); given the feasibility of recruitingchildren from the science center.
comments: The main comparisons are made between condition (1 = parent gain/friend lose; 0 = friend gain/parent lose); but the scale that is used (relationship quality) is entered as a moderator here. Afterwards; paired-sampled t-tests are performed for relationship quality between parents and friends. The samples are combined here; as you can see from the dfs (total N = 174): "Although parent relationship quality and friend relationship quality were correlated (r = .229; p = .002); participants reported greater levels of relationship quality with their friend than with their parent (parent: M = 3.72; friend: M = 4.21); t(173) = −8.90; p < .001. Even though participants reported higher quality relationships with a close friend; they were still overall more likely to make choices that benefited a par-ent at the expense of their friend. These were preplanned exploratory analyses for our first sample and confirmatory analyses for the second sample."

author: dore
comments: This is an analysis based on text; so I coded it non-empirical. Either way there are no group comparisons being made: "Participants in this study were users of an online appli-cation; called Koko (previously Panoply); that facilitates text-based emotional-support interactions within an anonymous social network (Morris et al.; 2015). We analyzed data from every user who interacted with this application between June 1; 2016; and June 20; 2017; a total of 169;376 unique users posted about 361;139 unique stressful situations and received 1;161;360 mes-sages of support in response"
